SENT.plain: An anticardiolipin antibody (ACA) assay has become a laboratory standard for the detection of antiphospholipid antibodies
We evaluated data from a quality assurance program to assess ACA assay usefulness
Cross-laboratory (n = 56) testing of 12 serum samples yielded interlaboratory coefficients of variation (CVs) for lgG ACA and IgM ACA that were higher than 50% in 17 (71%) of 24 cases
The situation for testing consensus was of equal concern
Total consensus occurred in 6 (25%) of 24 cases
General consensus (interlaboratory agreement, 90% or more) was obtained in 10 (42%) of 24 cases
In the majority of test cases, laboratories could not agree on whether a serum sample tested was ACA-positive or ACA-negative
Differing method-related issues also were evident; some methods tended toward higher or lower ACA values
Method-based majority consensus differed from participant majority consensus on many test occasions

Exceedingly high interlaboratory result variation, combined with a general lack of test result grading consensus and method-based variation, indicate that a cautious clinical approach toward laboratory findings is prudent
Laboratory tests should be repeated at least once before making a clinical diagnosis of any anti-phospholipid syndrome-like disorder
